programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Where We Call Home
programme.sub-title: A Temple's New Light of Hope
programme.desc: On this episode, we meet two foreigners living in Fukui - Jessie Shaku Hokai from Switzerland who's the abbess of a Buddhist temple, and Indonesian Rohimat Tri Saputra who works on a Welsh onion farm.

programme.title: Time-lapse Japan
programme.sub-title: HAGI: Vessels That Age with You
programme.desc: *First broadcast on January 26, 2026 Hagi ware has been cherished in tea ceremonies for over 400 years. Cracks in the glaze create patterns whose color evolves with time and use. Watch masterful pottery production in time-lapse.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Hometown Stories
programme.sub-title: The Island of Boze Deities
programme.desc: Despite earthquakes and isolation, the people of Akusekijima Island work to uphold local traditions, including the mysterious Boze deities. A new generation is helping to keep those traditions alive.

programme.title: Satoyama Kitchen Diary
programme.sub-title: Fancy and Flavorful Dried Persimmons
programme.desc: Hello there! It's me, Tama. Don't mind me, I just saw a hole and wanted to cool my paws in it. Looks like Grandpa Makoto and Grandma Nobuko are preparing their annual dried persimmons. So tasty! So sweet! But it takes weeks before they're ready! I don't know if I can wait that long!

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.sub-title: Foot and Leg
programme.desc: The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history and culture. This episode introduces words related to ashi, which means both foot and leg. They have many important pressure points and play a significant role in blood flow. They've even been called the "second heart." We follow poet, literary translator and long-time Japan resident Peter MacMillan as he takes a walk around his home in Kyoto Prefecture. He guides us through unique words and expressions along the way.

programme.title: Easy Japanese
programme.sub-title: #9 What is this?
programme.desc: When you see something for the first time and want to know what it is, just ask "kore wa nan desu ka."

programme.title: Culture Crossroads
programme.sub-title: Rakugo Leaps Over Language Barriers
programme.desc: RAMUNE, a descendant of Japanese emigrants to Brazil, is a performer of rakugo, Japan's traditional storytelling. Performing in multiple languages, she helps foreigners experience Japanese culture.

programme.title: HELLO! NHK WORLD-JAPAN
programme.sub-title: Introducing Multilingual Services at the Embassy of Bangladesh
programme.desc: With multilingual services, NHK WORLD-JAPAN helps foreign residents with disaster prevention and daily life. A presentation introducing these services was given at the Embassy of Bangladesh, in Tokyo.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Japanese Ballet's Global Challenge: Yoshida Miyako / Artistic Director
programme.desc: Yoshida Miyako performed around the world as a Royal Ballet principal dancer, and is now a top artistic director in Japan. She explains the challenges Japanese ballet faces on the international stage.

programme.title: On the Wings
programme.sub-title: Haneda to Fukuoka Airport
programme.desc: Join us on a night flight to admire Japan's stunning views on a journey from Tokyo to Fukuoka Prefecture. Behold the sublime beauty of Mt. Fuji at sunset and the sparkling night views of major cities.

programme.title: RAMEN JAPAN
programme.sub-title: Hiroshima
programme.desc: Two local takes on ramen that kept Hiroshima Prefecture fed during postwar reconstruction; flavors passed down for generations.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: Unruly Catfish
programme.desc: Japan is a seismically active land; the Edo period was no exception. In the aftermath of a major 1855 earthquake, an angry guardian deity sets off on a quest to capture those considered responsible.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Have You Written by Hand Lately? — The Value of Handwriting in the Digital Age
programme.desc: As the world continues to shift from handwriting to digital input, in Japan, an increasing number of people are forgetting how to write some kanji characters by hand. Recent studies show handwriting can help stimulate the brain and prevent cognitive decline. Indeed, schools in countries like Sweden and the United States are allocating more time on classes where students learn through writing by hand. With our guests, we explore the value of handwriting in this digital age. Guests: Itoi Shigesato (Copywriter) Otsuka Sadao (Associate Professor, Hyogo University of Teacher Education)

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.sub-title: Awaji Island: Mythical Birthplace of Japan
programme.desc: Awaji Island is the largest island in the Seto Inland Sea. From ancient times, Awaji has been known as "Japan's Foodstore," and local fish have, down the years, been presented to the Imperial Court. The island is also proud of its connection to the legend of the two gods, Izanagi and Izanami, who gave birth to Japan. The story of Japan's origins describes how the gods passed the country on to the people. Awaji Island is where it all began.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Medical Frontiers
programme.sub-title: Dementia: Long-Term Study Reveals New Findings
programme.desc: Hisayama Town in southern Japan has held health checkups since the 1960s. Using this data, Kyushu University identified two markers linked to early dementia. We present the latest findings.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.sub-title: Taketa: Onsen Bathing Old and New
programme.desc: People in Japan love bathing in hot springs, or onsen. And since the old days, it has been common for people to check into residential hot-spring inns for extended stays to boost their health, heal their aches and regain their well-being. This style of onsen therapeutics is known as Tōji. On this episode of Journeys in Japan, Kyle Card travels to Taketa City in Oita Prefecture to discover a contemporary style of Tōji therapy where visitors can recover their energy while enjoying the majestic natural environment along with some of the world's finest carbonated hot springs.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Dining with the Chef
programme.sub-title: Master Chef's Class: Chef Kuwakino's Rice-Based Plant Cuisine
programme.desc: Join Harry Sugiyama and chef Kuwakino for a fresh, fast master class in Veggie-full Japanese cooking, where rice takes center stage. Let's get cooking!

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Document 72 Hours
programme.sub-title: At a Huge Thrift Store in Saitama
programme.desc: Bargain-hunters and people decluttering their homes flock to a huge thrift store near Tokyo. For three days, we asked customers what drew them to this place filled with an array of second-hand goods.

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.sub-title: Nankai Trough Megaquake
programme.desc: A Nankai Trough megaquake is expected to cause severe damage. In this episode, we will examine how Japan is preparing for this impending disaster with cutting-edge technology.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Adapting Anime Costumes for Live-Action: Nakahara Sachiko / Stylist and Costume Designer
programme.desc: Nakahara Sachiko translates the looks of popular Japanese anime and manga characters into costumes for live-action adaptations. She talks about making an impact on the global stage.

programme.title: Nun's Seasonal Calendar
programme.sub-title: February
programme.desc: Join us as we learn about life at the Otowasan Kannonji Temple through 24 terms from the solar calendar. First, we follow the nuns on the day of Risshun. They enjoy colorful neko-mochi rice cakes, creating unique variations by adding unusual ingredients. Then they celebrate Girls' Day with a special tea ceremony on the day of Usui.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: A Napping Boy Dreams of Monsters
programme.desc: When a little boy's nap is disturbed by a bad dream, his mother comes to his rescue. What was terrorizing him? We examine a print that shows how much the Edo townspeople cherished their kids.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: A Napping Boy Dreams of Monsters
programme.desc: When a little boy's nap is disturbed by a bad dream, his mother comes to his rescue. What was terrorizing him? We examine a print that shows how much the Edo townspeople cherished their kids.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Aging Well: The Most Private Challenge
programme.desc: Japanese people are increasingly living longer lives, but the change is not always a welcome one. For many, the progression into old age, and the accompanying decline in bodily functions, results in continence issues. Many are reluctant to acknowledge the problem or accept outside help on such an intensely private matter. We asked experts how carers and loved ones can support people dealing with toileting issues, and consider how the elderly themselves can embrace a positive shift in perspective to get the most out of their final stage of life. Guests: Gondo Yasuyuki (Professor, Graduate School of Human Sciences, The University of Osaka), Urata Katsumi (Certified Nurse in Wound, Ostomy and Continence Nursing with Advanced Practice Authorization)

programme.title: Document 72 Hours
programme.sub-title: At a Huge Thrift Store in Saitama
programme.desc: Bargain-hunters and people decluttering their homes flock to a huge thrift store near Tokyo. For three days, we asked customers what drew them to this place filled with an array of second-hand goods.

programme.title: Dive in Tokyo
programme.sub-title: Koishikawa – Historic Charm and Industry Nurtured by Water
programme.desc: Koishikawa is a residential area in the city center that is home to a botanical garden and a temple associated with the Edo shogunate. As we explore, we discover a legacy of printing and bookbinding.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Considering Our Future Through Dinosaur Research: Kobayashi Yoshitsugu / Paleontologist / Professor, Hokkaido University
programme.desc: In June 2025, Kobayashi Yoshitsugu published a trailblazing paper, illuminating the evolutionary process of large tyrannosaurs. He explains how such research helps us consider the future of humanity.

programme.title: Japan's Top Inventions
programme.sub-title: Non-Loosening Bolts
programme.desc: Discover the stories behind renowned Japanese products alongside our reporter. This time: non-loosening bolts.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: FRONTRUNNERS
programme.sub-title: Dry Stone Waller: Kaneko Reo
programme.desc: Much of the stonework supporting Japan's terraced fields is in danger of collapse. There's an urgent need to train new stonemasons to carry out repairs. Kaneko Reo runs workshops around the country.

programme.title: KABUKI KOOL
programme.sub-title: Devoted Love and Warring Clans
programme.desc: Unswerving Devotion: The Japanese Twenty-Four Examples of Filial Piety. Kataoka Ainosuke is our guide to a play featuring a kabuki princess in a story of warring clans and the magic of a sacred helmet. Princess Yaegaki holding the sacred helmet and surrounded by the magical foxes. With the help of the magic of the foxes, she goes to save her lover's life.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Dive in Tokyo
programme.sub-title: Koishikawa – Historic Charm and Industry Nurtured by Water
programme.desc: Koishikawa is a residential area in the city center that is home to a botanical garden and a temple associated with the Edo shogunate. As we explore, we discover a legacy of printing and bookbinding.

programme.title: NEWSLINE ASIA 24
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Considering Our Future Through Dinosaur Research: Kobayashi Yoshitsugu / Paleontologist / Professor, Hokkaido University
programme.desc: In June 2025, Kobayashi Yoshitsugu published a trailblazing paper, illuminating the evolutionary process of large tyrannosaurs. He explains how such research helps us consider the future of humanity.

programme.title: Japan's Top Inventions
programme.sub-title: Non-Loosening Bolts
programme.desc: Discover the stories behind renowned Japanese products alongside our reporter. This time: non-loosening bolts.

programme.title: NEWSLINE ASIA 24
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: FRONTRUNNERS
programme.sub-title: Dry Stone Waller: Kaneko Reo
programme.desc: Much of the stonework supporting Japan's terraced fields is in danger of collapse. There's an urgent need to train new stonemasons to carry out repairs. Kaneko Reo runs workshops around the country.

programme.title: Science View
programme.sub-title: Origami Engineering - Unfolding Hidden Potential
programme.desc: Japan's traditional papercraft, origami, has come to be used in engineering, as researchers observe insects and other specimens to develop "crease patterns" that can be utilized in diverse fields.

programme.title: NHK NEWS 7
programme.desc: News 7 is NHK's flagship domestic evening news program, bringing you the latest from our Tokyo studio. It's presented with English audio on NHK World for our international viewers

programme.title: Dive in Tokyo
programme.sub-title: Koishikawa – Historic Charm and Industry Nurtured by Water
programme.desc: Koishikawa is a residential area in the city center that is home to a botanical garden and a temple associated with the Edo shogunate. As we explore, we discover a legacy of printing and bookbinding.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Wastewater Research for Public Health: Kitajima Masaaki / Project Professor, Research Center for Water Environment Technology, The University of Tokyo
programme.desc: In 2020, Kitajima Masaaki published the world's first paper on how the spread of COVID-19 could be tracked by monitoring wastewater. He talks about making an impact on infectious disease control.

programme.title: Herbal Symphony
programme.sub-title: Winter – Jewels at Our Feet
programme.desc: Winter in Japan's oldest private herb garden in Uda, Nara Prefecture. As fallen leaves and withered grass cover the ground, the search begins for treasures hidden beneath the frozen soil.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: Ritual Purification at Roben Falls
programme.desc: We journey to a sacred mountain where pilgrims are purifying themselves in a waterfall before moving on. Some of them have even brought along offerings ... and it turns out they have something to prove.

programme.title: Trails to Oishii Tokyo
programme.sub-title: Wagyu
programme.desc: Wagyu captivates food lovers worldwide with fine marbling, melt-in-the-mouth texture, and rich aroma. Join us as we explore strict cattle management and the dishes that highlight wagyu's appeal. Reporter: Safiya Quinley
